Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Award: Social and Environmental Impacts of Village Formation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research examines how social and environmental contexts are altered as groups of individuals aggregate and settle into sedentary village life. This is a cultural transformation that has occurred in many different societies across the world. The formation of villages requires a dramatic social and cultural reorganization, which entails a redefinition of social networks, personal and collective identities, and space and place, as people adjust to their new mode of living. This research will focus on the patterns of continuity and change in interaction and integration across time and space to explore the social processes involved in the cultural transformations that occurred prior to village formation. This process which started thousands of years ago continues today and is fueled by worldwide social mobility. This research also provides training and experience in curation procedures and fieldwork to several undergraduate students, which will assist them in developing the necessary skills to pursue a career in archaeology

This research is concerned with understanding the social interactions and integration among communities that occurred just prior to village formation. Recent research has suggested that the basic social structure of village life developed alongside increasing sedentism, prior to the formation of villages. The Early Pithouse period (A.D. 200 to 700) in the Mogollon region of southwestern New Mexico and southeastern Arizona is ideally suited for this research because it marks just this step of the process. To explore these negotiations, this research uses a multi-scalar, historical framework that focuses on social interactions and integration among communities of practice. The data for this research will rely on ceramics, obsidian, and architectural features from existing artifact collections and excavation reports as well as an ongoing excavation project. Social interaction will be examined through pottery circulation, analyzed through instrumental neutron activation analysis and petrographic analysis, as well as obsidian procurement, analyzed through x-ray fluorescence. Integration among communities will be examined through technological and stylistic attributes of ceramics and architecture. In addition, accelerator mass spectrometry dating of radiocarbon samples will be used to further refine the chronology of the Mogollon Early Pithouse period. The results of these analyses will be compared across time and space to gain an understanding of how people negotiated their social and physical landscapes prior to village formation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The process of becoming villages is a cultural transformation that occurred in many different societies around the world. To understand the developmental trajectory of village formation, it is important to not only understand the processes of this transformation, but also the processes leading up to this transformation. The Early Pithouse period (AD 200-700) in the Mogollon region of southwestern New Mexico and southeastern Arizona represents one of these transitional periods when people were just starting to work through the social negotiations needed for village formation. Barkwill Love analyzed ceramics, obsidian, and charred plant remains from seven Early Pithouse (AD 200-700) sites to gain an understanding of the social interaction and integration among communities that occurred prior to village formation. Neutron activation analysis (NAA) of ceramics and x-ray fluorescence (XRF) of obsidian were used to examine social interaction. Integration among communities was examined through technological and stylistic attributes of ceramics as well as radiocarbon dating of charred plant remains and Bayesian chronological modeling.

The results of the NAA showed that the pottery was not all locally made as generally believed. All seven sites had pottery that came from multiple sources. This suggests that there was considerable movement of pottery and/or people at these sites. Therefore, social boundaries were likely fluid and open during the Early Pithouse period. The XRF of obsidian showed a different pattern in which most of the obsidian came from a single source. However, it should be noted that only three of the seven sites had an appreciable amount of obsidian, and those that did were located close to the source. Therefore, it is possible that obsidian was a resource of convenience and not a valued or traded resource during the Early Pithouse period.

The results from the ceramic analysis showed that there is a general similarity in the technological and stylistic attributes across the sites, which likely suggests fluid social boundaries. In addition, total of 38 new radiocarbon dates were run for this project, which confirmed the placement in the Early Pithouse period for four sites (Mogollon Village, McAnally, SU, and Mesa Top) as well as provided dates for two previously undated Early Pithouse period sites (Two Boots and Thompson). A detailed Bayesian chronological analysis was conducted at Mogollon Village to examine contemporaneity of the pithouses. The Bayesian chronological modeling showed that Mogollon Village was occupied for at least 585 to 785 years; however, there were likely few contemporary pithouses at any given time. Thus, Mogollon Village is best viewed as a palimpsest of small occupations. This research suggested that prior to village formation in the Mogollon region, people were mobile with open social boundaries; however, there was likely a connection to certain locations on the landscape.

This research provided the doctoral candidate with the opportunity to utilize archaeological collections that had not received much attention and gain experience in museum curation procedures as well as design and conduct an archaeological excavation. This in turn allowed the doctoral candidate to provide training and experience in museum curation and field excavations to undergraduates. Overall this research contributes to the understanding of the early ceramic period in the Mogollon region as well as the developmental trajectories of early village formation.
